fields.title: Getting started
fields.content:
#Quick start guide

In this short guide, we demonstrate a few Markdown Notes features. Even if you know Markdown, Markdown Notes has quite a few neat hidden features.

This note is editable, so feel free play around and break things.

##1. Quick markdown primer

Markdown is a simple document formatting language used by Stack Overflow, Github and a bunch of other sites. Markdown Notes uses [Github-flavored markdown](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown). You can safely open your notes in another editor and they will display just fine.

###1.1. Basic formatting

* **Bold**, *italics* and ~~strikethrough~~ text is really simple
* [Links](http://markdownnotes.com) are also easily created
* Titles are created by adding `#`'s at the beginning of the line.
* A single line break creates a second line. Two line breaks create a paragraph.

> Use angled brackets to cite your favorite authors

###1.2. Lists

You create lists by adding a `*` at the begining of the line. You can indent your lists by adding spaces before the `*`.

* List item 1
* List item 2
	* Sublist 1
    	* Sublist item 1
        * Sublist item 2
    * Sublist 2
* List item 3

Numbered lists are pretty easy to create too:

1. Item one
	1. Subitem one
    2. Subitem two
    
You can also mix lists if you feel like it:

1. List item 1
	* Subitem 1
2. List item 2
	1. Subitem 1
    
You can also create nestedto-do lists:

* [x] This one is done
* [ ] This one is not
    * [ ] This is a subtask
    * [ ] test
    	* [ ] Do this first
    	* [x] Do this next
* [ ] Neither is this one

###1.3. Code blocks

You can create syntax-highlighted code blocks by using three backticks. The code will be highlighted automatically:

```
public class HelloWorld {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Hello, World");
    }
}
```

For `inline code`, use a single backtick.

###1.4. LaTeX

Wrap your LaTeX equations with two `$`'s for inline equations and three `$`'s for equation blocks.

You can create an inline equation for $$3n+\sum_2^n{\pi}$$ or put it in a block:

$$$
3n+\sum_2^n{\pi}
$$$

###1.5. Images

Images can be dragged and dropped over the editor. Alternatively, you can use the standard markdown syntax:

![my image](http://markdownnotes.com/static/img/cloud.png)

##2. Editor features

Markdown Notes provides convenient features that make note-taking easier.

###2.1. Preview and editor modes

Use the *Editor*, *Preview* and *Editor + Preview* modes at the top of the window to toggle the editor and the preview.

###2.2. Printing notes

All your notes are printable. Print them like any other webpage, and the output will be formatted like a professional document. The markdown code will not show on the printed page.

###2.3. Automatic save

Your notes are saved automatically when you stop typing. 

###2.4. Exporting notes

Click the *Export* button at the top of the page to export your notes to `.md` files. These files can be opened by any markdown editor, although you might not get full support for unique features such as LaTeX equations.

###2.5. Code folding

Click the small `▾` icons at the left of the editor to collapse the section under them. Click it again to reveal the hidden sections.

###2.6. Keyboard shortcuts

The following standard shortcuts are supported:

* **Bold text:** `Ctrl+B`
* **Italics:** `Ctrl+I`
* **Link:** `Ctrl+K`
* **Print:** `Ctrl+P`

fields.title: Hello there!
fields.content:
#Hello there!

This is a fully functional editor, so feel free to play around for a bit before you sign up.

New to markdown? Open the **menu** above and select the note titled "**Getting started**" to see what Markdown Notes can do.
